coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Using angle-resolved photoemission with synchrotron radiation, we have identified the molecular orbitais and the final state shape resonance behavior of CO adsorbed on clean and potassium promoted Ru(0001) (θK = 0.33). Although vibrational spectroscopy and thermal desorption isotopic scrambling indicate severely weakened C-O bonds, we do not observe corresponding shifts in the shape resonance transition energy of the 4σ level indicating that there is no simple relationship between bond length and shape resonance energy.

Upton, NY 11973, USA Received 10 November 1985 Using angle-resolved photoemission with synchrotron radiation, we have identified the molecular orbitais and the final state shape resonance behavior of CO adsorbed on clean and potassium promoted Ru(OOOl) (fl^ =0.33). Although vibrational spectroscopy and thermal desorption isotopic scrambling indicate severely weakened C 0 bonds, we do not observe corresponding shifts in the shape resonance transition energy of the 4 o level indicating that there is no simple relationship between bond length and shape resonance energy. Recent experiments on alkali promoted transition metal surfaces have demonstrated anomalously weak C 0 bonds for coadsorbed carbon monoxide, which manifest themselves in large downshift of the C-0 stretch frequency [1,2] and an increase in vibrational overtone anharmomcities [2]. Facile C 0 bond break- ing was either observed via increasing dissociation rate [3 6] or by isotopic scrambling in thermal desorption experiments [2,7]. Both vibrational and thermokinetic data clearly indicate substantial weakening and length- ening of the C 0 bond. Analogies to both metal car- bonyls [8] and molecularly adsorbed oxygen on Pt(l 11) [9] thus suggest a dramatic C-0 bond length- ening by 0.1 to 0.2 A m comparison to the gas-phase molecule [2]. This bond length change should not only affect the electronic structure of the molecule [10], but also its final state shape resonance. Recent theoretical [11] and experimental work [9] have sug- gested that the shape resonance should be rather sen- 0 009-2614/86/$ 03.50 Eisevier Science Publishers B.V. [12] reported a shift of several eV of the Ols and Cis shape resonance transition energy for coadsorbed CO and Na on Pt(l 11), which they used to extract a bond lengthening by 0.12 A. Here we investigate the shape resonance behavior for a valence orbital (4o) excitation. This is an ad- sorbate system, where drastic bond lengthening has been demonstrated with other probes. We have chosen the case, where CO is coadsorbed with a monolayer of potassium (OcQ = 0.33,9^ = -33) o" a Ru(0001) sur- face. This system has been well characterized in pre- vious investigations using vibrational spectroscopy [13,14], photoemission [15,16] and other surface probes [17]. The strong frequency shift of this mode from its gas phase value (2143 cm"1) indicates substantial C 0 bond weakening. This has been most recently demonstrated with EELS overtone spectroscopy, which has shown overtone anharmonici- ties for these red-shifted C 0 stretches ten times larger compared to gas-phase CO [14]. These highly anhar- monic C 0 potential wells indicate severe bond weak- ening. Additionally, thermal desorption experiments, reveal complete isotopic scrambling between ^C^O and ^C^O. In contrast, CO does not at all exhibit any isotopic scrambling on the unpromoted clean Ru(0001) surface [2,14,17] and the CO stretching mode is observed at 2015 cm"1 as shown in the insert in fig. 1. In order to study the electronic structure of this system, we have used angte-resolved photoemission to (i) identify the molecular orbitais according to their symmetry and (ii) examine the final state shape reso- nance for a possible shift correlated with a change in C 0 bond length between CO chemisorbed on clean and potassium modified ruthenium. The experiments were performed at the Tantalus I storage ring at the Synchrotron Radiation Center of the University of Wisconsin Madison using a toroidal monochromator (TGM) and an angle-resolving photo- electron spectrometer described elsewhere (see foot- hv(eV) Fig. 2. The inset shows in comparison the lir level of CO for clean and potassium promoted CO obtained in for- bidden geometry (see text) at hv = 31 eV. note +). As reported earlier [15], the most pronounced difference in the photoemission spectra between CO adsorbed on a clean and potassium promoted Ru(OOOl) surface is a 1 1.5 eV upward shift of the Iff CO level ( ='6.3 eV). This is shown in the insert in fig. 2, where spectra for CO (6cQ = 0.33) adsorbed on clean Ru(0001) and potassium promoted Ru(0001) (6^ = 033,0cQ = 0.33) are compared. Both spectra have been obtained under identical conditions, i.e. with normal incident light (31 e V) in the forbidden collec- tion geometry (20 polar angle and azimuth perpen- dicular to the plane of light polarization). CO on clean Ru exhibits the usual behavior of level ordering and symmetry as on other high index transition metal sur- faces (table 1). The small remnant of the 4o emission can be accounted for by the incomplete polarization of the light. On the K modified surface, however, we observe two distinct differences in the CO levels. The emission from the 4o and 5a orbitais is reduced but 238 Volume 124, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 21 February 1986 Table 1 CO binding energies (eV) 4o lir 5o Ru(0001) 10.8 7.7 7.8 K/Ru(0001)( K = 0.33 11.2 6.5 7.9 not completely extinct in the forbidden geometry, and the Iff emission is shifted by about 1.2 eV to lower binding energy. Incomplete polarization of the light transmitted through the TGM cannot account for the appearance of the 4o and 5o peaks in the forbidden geometry. Therefore, we conclude that the symmetry of the CO molecules is broken. A possible explanation for this result could be that the molecules are slightly tilted or that there exists a rather low-energy "wagging" mode of the molecule on the K modified surface that produces an average tilt of the molecule. From the rel- ative reduction of the 4a and 5o emission we estimate that the apparent tilt angle is less than 30 . The near normal orientation of the CO molecule also is consis- tent with the angular profile of the 4a shape resonance emission and the geometry determined for CO/Na on Pt [12]. At present, however, we favor the explanation that the symmetry is broken by an electronic interac- tion as reported earlier [15]. Incidentally, our 5o/lff assignment is opposite to recently published results [16] ; however, the polarization dependence as well as the variation in cross section with photon energy make an error in our assignment unlikely. In a previous publication [15] we have dealt with the involvement of the Iff orbital in the CO surface bond of the K modified surface. Since the Iff orbital is strongly bonding with respect to CO any change in this orbital upon adsorption will have its effect on the CO bond too. Together with 2ir back bonding this change in the ff orbital system should result in a bond lengthening of the CO bond. Whether the CO bond length is changed and, therefore, the Iff orbital energy is smaller or whether the Iff is shifted by the interac- tion with the substrate electron causing the CO bond to weaken is immaterial since all these changes are related self-consistently. The end result is the same. More important, the observed increase in the 4a to Iff energy splitting is consistent with a substantial increase in the C 0 bond length CiO.l A), according to calcu- lations of Rosen et al. [10]. Correspondingly, we ex- pect an energy shift in the final shape resonance of the 4o orbital, when comparing the clean and potassi- um promoted surfaces [11,20]. Having established a CO bond lengthening on the K modified surface by several independent pieces of in- formation we are very surprised to find the 4a shape resonance transition energy not to change between CO and clean Ru(0001) and on the K modified surface (as shown in fig. 2). Previously a direct relationship be- tween the shape resonance energy and interatomic distances in gas phase molecules was well established by theory [11] and verified experimentally [20]. A similar relationship seemd to be valid for adsorbed molecules on surfaces [9]. According to these studies a 0.1 A bond lengthening of the CO would result in a 3 to 4 e V shift of the shape resonance to lower energy. Clearly our data show that the shape resonance shifts less than 1 eV, taking small initial state shifts (0.4 eV) in the 4o level into account. A similar result was ob- tained for CO + K on Cu( 100) as well [21 ]. We have to point out some differences in the detec- tion of the shape resonance between our work and the previous studies [9,20], even though we are convinced that they do not explain the different behavior. We have studied the transition from the 4a initial state into the final state continuum shape resonance in direct photoemission. Incidentally, the emission in the shape resonance is highly peaked in the direction of the mo- lecular axis [11,22] and the angular width we observe is roughly in agreement with the less than 30 tilt esti- mate discussed above. Contrary to our experimental technique, the previous shape resonance shifts were observed in absorption (yield) spectroscopy at the Cis and Ols core excitation thresholds. The 4o wavefunc- tion is certainly more extended than the Ols, but it is also localized at the 0 atom which is away from the surface. Since we are comparing shifts between the shape resonance of the same initial state in the ad- sorbed state between clean Ru and K precovered Ru any effect due to a difference in initial state holes should cancel out. We take our observation of an unchanged resonance energy, even though the CO bond length is different between the two adsorption cases, as evidence for strong perturbation of the final state potential caused by the presence of the K atoms. The shape resonance is very sensitive, indeed, to the exact shape of the po- 239 Volume 124, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 21 February 1986 tential since it is quasibound by the angular momen- tum barriers m the final state [9,22]. Any modifica- tion of the shape of this barrier will also influence the energy and existence of the shape resonance. Even in the "normal" CO adsorption on clean Ru the C side of this potential barrier will be certainly different than for gas phase CO. In the case of the K precovered sur- face CO is adsorbed actually "deep inside" the K over- layer because of the large radius of the K atoms. Possi- bly the change in the final state potential that is asso- ciated with the CO bond lengthening in this case is largely compensated for by the change due to the pres- ence of the K atoms right next to the CO molecule. Another factor worth considering is that the line- shape of the shape resonance is determined by a Franck Condon envelope over the vibrational motion of the molecule. As Dehmer and co-workers pointed out [ 11 ], the large width ( 5 eV) of the shape reso- nance is caused by the averaging over the nuclear mo- tion. Since the vibrational properties of CO on clean Ru and on K promoted Ru are vastly different, the Franck Condon envelope should be different for both cases and this might cause an apparent shift in either direction of the observed resonance transition energy. We want to mention here without a long discussion that photoemission and absorption spectroscopy probe the system on a different timescale. However, the nu- clear motion is slow compared to either timescale. In general it is conceivable that absorption spectra display states (or structures) which will not show up in the photoemission cross section. Inversely, however, the photoemission total cross section variations have to show up in an absorption spectrum. Clearly our data demonstrate the need for detailed theoretical calculations but should also serve the ex- perimentalists as warning that the final state shape resonances of adsorbed molecules not only reflect changes in the molecular geometry upon adsorption but also are dependent on changes in the detailed shape of the electrostatic potential at the surface.
